title: 113_hr1929
content: The Act is titled the "Enhancing Employment and Training Through Education Act of 2013". It includes pilot projects to reduce dependency and increase work effort in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program. The Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 is amended to include pilot projects aimed at reducing dependency and increasing work effort in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program. These projects will identify best practices for employment and training programs to help participants secure unsubsidized employment, raise their earned income, and decrease reliance on public assistance. Selection criteria for the pilot projects will be based on established criteria by the Secretary. The Secretary will establish criteria for pilot projects in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program, including enhancing employment and training programs, participating in evaluations, collaborating with workforce boards, ensuring replicability, and meeting additional criteria for project success. The Secretary will establish criteria for pilot projects in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program to target various populations of work registrants and include a range of employment and training programs. The Secretary will establish pilot projects in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program to target different populations of work registrants and offer a variety of employment and training programs. These projects will provide post-employment support services, education leading to credentials, and evaluations of selected projects. The projects will be located in diverse geographic areas and include participants who are exempt and not exempt under specific sections. The Secretary will conduct pilot projects in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program targeting various work registrant populations. These projects will offer diverse employment and training programs, post-employment support services, and evaluations. Geographic diversity and participants exempt and not exempt under specific sections will be included. An independent evaluation will measure the impact on employment, household income, and reduced dependency. A report to Congress detailing project results is due by September 30, 2017. The Secretary will conduct pilot projects in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program targeting work registrant populations. The projects will evaluate impact on employment, income, and public benefit receipt, as well as costs and dissemination of findings. $10,000,000 will be available annually from 2014 to 2016 for incorporating successful project components into State programs. The Secretary will allocate $10,000,000 annually from 2014 to 2016 for pilot projects in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program. Funds will be used for project compliance, administration, data provision, and evaluation costs. Funds allocated for pilot projects in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program cannot be used to replace non-Federal funds for existing employment and training activities.
